sourceMeaningMnemonic: There's a <radical>cross</radical> sticking out the top of the <radical>sun</radical> and another <radical>cross</radical> sticking out the bottom. The <radical>moon</radical> is off to the right. That's because it's the <kanji>morning</kanji>, which is when the sun and moon switch over. Those crosses are making sure the sun stays high in the sky for the rest of the day.
meaningInfo: Imagine a sun attached up in the sky with two crosses, which act as scaffolding, and the moon gradually fading off to the right as the morning wears on.
readingMnemonic: Every <kanji>morning</kanji> you have <reading>Asa</reading>hi (<ja>あさ</ja>) beer for breakfast.
readingInfo: You watch the sun scaffolded by crosses, and the moon next to it, as you sip on your early-morning Asahi.
